entry.title: Re: I want to change the background color when there is n...
entry.content:
I believe you can achieve the desired result using threshold with an extra trick.

Threshold can be used to color cells in a table based on the cell value w/o showing the value itself. This cannot directly be used on NULL cells. But if you define a calculation that converts NULL to a numeric values which is very unlikely to appear, then this can be used to define a threshold coloring the background of the cell.

I was using the following steps for a Universal Measure Model:

  1. Add a calcuated member to the structure dimension using this formula: IF(ISNULL( [#Measure Values]) ,999999999999 ,[#Measure Values]
  2. Ensure the structure dimension is assigned to the free axis (not assigned to an axis) and filtered to this new member
  3. Define a threshold for neutral range and values between >= 999999999999 < 1000000000000
  4. Customize the color used for this threshold
  5. apply table styling for threshold style=Color Background without Values

I see one issue with this trick: The hard coded value does not have a unit. The original table showed the same unit in every cell and thus could extract the common unit to the table title. This is no longer possible with the hard coded value that does not have a unit.

entry.title: Re: Open Vendor Confirming Items in SAP Public Cloud
entry.content:
As per this SAP Help the mass migration of accounts payable open items with the special G/L indicator referring to the special G/L type 'W' must be posted manually in financial accounting. This also means, SAP does not support automated migration of open items involving Special G/L type W via tools like:

  • SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit
  • BAPI_ACC_DOCUMENT_POST
  • Direct staging table uploads

To handle this correctly, follow this two-step workaround:

Use the migration cockpit or staging tables to migrate the vendor invoice only (without the CME payment). Leave the payment portion out of the automated migration.

After migration, manually post the Special G/L payment using FB01 or F-53 with the appropriate Special G/L indicator. This ensures the payment is correctly linked and reflected in the system. If you're dealing with a large volume of such items, consider using batch input sessions to automate FB01 entries

entry.title: Re: Smartforms barcode with barcode content embedded as i...
entry.content: To print a barcode in a Purchase Order PDF Smartform in SAP, first select the desired barcode type (e.g., Code 128) and ensure the corresponding font is installed on the SAP system. Access the Smartforms transaction (SMARTFORMS) to create or modify the relevant Smartform. Add a text element where the barcode will appear, format the barcode value (e.g., using concatenation to include start and stop characters), and set the font to the installed barcode font. Adjust the layout as needed, then save and activate the Smartform.

entry.title: Re: Verification of Payee (VoP) - What is planned in SAP S/4HANA Cloud ERP
entry.content:
@dvid 

1. We have no general FAQ, but we could create one. 

2. Order type derivation in S/4 is done via configuration. That needs to be done by each customer. Within Multi-Bank Connectivity only the response order type (for pain.002) has to be registered (I linked the description how to open a service request) witihin the text). 

3. With Bank Portal we refer to online banking.  

4. Regarding pulling, I would not expect that it is necesarry to change your cycle. 5-10 seconds is the defined reaction time between PSPs, there is no definition how fast you need to react on the verification result. You could even authorize/reject days later.

entry.title: Re: Story report calculating average years of service- calculator delivering inaccurate information
entry.content: just a small suggestion for creating stories, it's always a good idea to add a table and see the data per person in a cross-tab. You can have your people and their tenure and this might give you an insight what's wrong there. It can be duplication of rows (same person appears several times or something else). You need to debug it on a person level and not the total measure level

entry.title: Converting Group Financial Data to separate Chart of Accounts
entry.content:
Hi there,

We have a requirement to transform consolidated financial data into a separate chart of accounts that is native to a companies holding company (Outside of SAP). The financial data/balances will need to be reported at the G/L level of their CoA. Since we are leveraging the YCOA of operational postings in the spirit of fit to standard methodology, we came up with the following solutions:

  • Explode the FS item registry to be 1 to 1 relationship with YCOA. Likely making the FS item imitating the YCOA. Then leverage FS Item Hierarchy to display the FS item balances in the holding companies CoA, using different nodes. Is there a concern with exploding the FS item registry, as standard typically follows the most granular line item of the financial statement. However global hierarchies can do this for us as well. 
  • Leverage "Group Account Number" from the G/L Account Master Data to maintain the holding companies CoA. Then export financial data using "Group Data Analysis" to report the group account number as a dimension. This solution seems logical, but my concern is the future state of this field. Is there a chance this field gets deprecated in the future? My other concern, is that when exporting financial statement item data, through "Group Data Analysis", the system losses visibility at the YCOA level when crossing over fiscal years. For example, when a balance carry forward is complete, all "account number" details from previous fiscal years is summarized as "#", see below:
    •  

    •  

       

       

Happy to hear other suggestions. Your thoughts are welcomed!

Arthur.

entry.title: Integrating SAP Process Orchestration into an Event-Driven Architecture with SAP Advanced Event Mesh
entry.content:
As organizations accelerate their digital transformation, event-driven architecture (EDA) has emerged as a powerful approach for building scalable, real-time, and loosely coupled systems. Solutions like SAP Advanced Event Mesh serve as enterprise-grade event brokers that support asynchronous messaging patterns across hybrid and cloud-native landscapes.

On the other end of the spectrum lies SAP Process Orchestration - a robust, time-tested middleware platform still running mission-critical integrations in many enterprises. While SAP has officially announced the end-of-life of SAP Process Orchestration, with long-term support ending in the coming years, replacing it entirely is often a long, phased journey.

This blog post is not about extending the life of SAP Process Orchestration indefinitely, but rather about integrating it into your modern architecture—bridging the gap between legacy and modern systems. By connecting SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Advanced Event Mesh via JMS with JNDI, you can start to decouple systems and adopt EDA principles without a complete rip-and-replace.

We assume you're familiar with setting up scenarios in Process Orchestration, so we’ll skip over iFlow configuration and focus instead on:

  • Deploying Solace JMS libraries in SAP Process Orchestration
  • Configuring SAP Advanced Event Mesh for JNDI (Java Naming and Directory Interface) support
  • Setting up the JMS receiver channel in Process Orchestration to connect to Advanced Event Mesh

This approach provides a low-friction way to modernize the edge of your SAP Process Orchestration integrations while planning for long-term migration. It enables you to offload responsibilities to the event broker, reduce point-to-point connections, and pave the way for loosely coupled microservices or SAP Integration Suite adoption. Let’s dive in.

Use Case

Our integration scenario is as follows:

  1. REST Sender Adapter receives a message from Postman or any REST client to reliably test the setup.
  2. Process Orchestration routes the message to a JMS Receiver Adapter.
  3. The JMS Receiver connects to Advanced Event Mesh via JNDI, and publishes the message to a target queue.

Prerequisites

  • SAP Process Orchestration 7.5 or newer (Java-only stack preferred)
  • Access to SAP Advanced Event Mesh
  • Admin access to the Advanced Event Mesh Broker Manager for configuration
  • SAP NetWeaver Administrator access to deploy shared libraries

Step 1: Download the Solace JMS Library

As with most integration scenarios with Advanced Event Mesh our first starting point is the Connect tab of your Cluster Manager. We are interested in using the Solace JMS API which uses the Solace Message Format (SMF) as a protocol and can find all the information we need there:

 

  • Go to Get Started to find further documentations of the API and more importantly downloads for the sol-jms library.
  • When choosing a version for the sol-jms library it is crucial to understand any required dependencies. Feel free to familiarize yourself with the Solace provided API documentation regarding supported Java environments and dependencies.
    https://docs.solace.com/API/Solace-JMS-API/JMS-API-supported-environments.htm
  • For this blog I decided to go with a JMS 1.1 implementation which makes sol-jms-10.19.0 a good choice to keep dependencies to a minimum since as of version 10.20, the Solace Messaging API for JMS has a dependency on JMS 2.0 and would require a compatibility layer.
  • Using this version, the only dependencies needed in my case were
    • Apache Commons Logging (This blog uses commons-logging-1.1.3)
    • A implementation of the JMS 1.1 specification for messaging in Java applications (This blog uses geronimo-jms_1.1_spec-1.1.1)
  • Feel free to experiment with different versions or even a JMS 2.0 implementation, but make sure to include dependencies accordingly!

Step 2: Deploy Solace JMS Library in SAP Process Orchestration

Generally the activity of deploying external drivers such as JMS libraries into the Java stack of SAP Process Orchestration is done by Basis, so as a developer you might not necessarily have the required access and/or knowledge to perform this. The following is just an outline of the process. For more guidance refer to the following blog:
How to Deploy External JMS and JDBC drivers in SAP PO 7.5

  • Package the relevant JAR files you identified in the previous section (sol-jms and dependencies) into a Software Deployment Archive (SDA). You will either need to add the JAR files to the currently deployed SDA of your Process Orchestration or deploy a new one from scratch.
  • After creating your SDA deploy it to the Java stack. This can be done for example using SAP NetWeaver Developer Studio (NWDS) and requires administrator access.
  • After successful deployment you should be able to find your resources in the Java Class Loader:

Step 3: Configure JNDI in SAP Advanced Event Mesh

To facilitate establishing the JMS connection between SAP Process Orchestration and SAP Advanced Event Mesh in the easiest way possible we are going to make use of JNDI. While it is most certainly possible to setup a generic JMS Receiver in Process Orchestration without JNDI it will not be covered in this blog. Instead head to your Advanced Event Mesh Console to:

  1. Enable JNDI Access
    • Select your Broker in the Cluster Manager and open the corresponding Broker Manager.
    • Navigate to Messaging > JMS JNDI.
    • Enable JNDI if not yet enabled under JNDI Settings and create a JNDI Connection Factory.
      • In this example I chose /JNDI/TEST for the Connection Factory
      • The rest of the Connection Factory settings are left at default, but feel free to adjust transport properties as necessary.
  2. Define the Queue
    • Go to Messaging > Queues.
    • Create a Queue
      • In this case I called it T28_JMS according to the ID of my SAP Process Orchestration system, adjust as necessary
      • Ensure is enabled and properly permissioned.
  3. Bind Queue and Connection Factory to JNDI
    • Under JMS JNDI > Queues, create a new JMS Queue
      • The JNDI Name defines how we are going to address this queue from Process Orchestration. I chose is /JNDI/T28_JMS to keep naming consistent with the..
      • Physical Name, where you select the actual queue you just created in Advanced Event Mesh

Step 4: Configure JMS Receiver Channel in SAP Process Orchestration

Here’s the setup of the JMS Receiver Adapter:

Parameters:

  • Adapter Type: JMS
  • Transport Protocol: Access JMS Provider with JNDI
  • Message Protocol: JMS 1.x

Connection Parameters:

  • Name of JNDI Initial Context Factory:
    com.solacesystems.jndi.SolJNDIInitialContextFactory is the initial Context Factory provided by the sol-jms library
  • JNDI Lookup Name of Topic/QueueConnectionFactory & JMS Queue/Topic:
    This is what we just created in the Advanced Event Mesh, in my case /JNDI/TEST and /JNDI/T28_JMS
  • JNDI Server Address,  Logon User & Password:
    You can find the Server Address and credentials for the default user solace-cloud-client under the Connect tab in the Cluster Manager of your AEM broker where we got the sol-jms library in the beginning. Be sure to include the Message VPN in the JNDI Logon User with an '@' symbol.
  • The solace-cloud-client user should only be used for development purposes. Be sure to create a proper client via Broker Manager > Access Control in your Advanced Event Mesh for productive use.

After configuring your JMS Receiver Adapter make sure the other parts of this scenario are ready as well and activate them.

Step 5: Test via the REST API platform of your choice

  1. Send a test payload to your REST endpoint. In my case I will send a very basic XML message.


  2. The scenario processes and routes the message to the JMS Receiver channel.


  3. The Message will get published to the queue specified in Advanced Event Mesh. You can monitor this by checking in the Broker Manager > Queues that your queue is receiving messages.

Troubleshooting Tips

  • ClassNotFoundException: Ensure the sol-jms library and dependencies are correctly deployed.
  • JNDI Lookup Failures: Confirm the JNDI names in Process Orchestration match exactly with those configured in Advanced Event Mesh.
  • Security Errors: Check that the user has appropriate permissions in the Advanced Event Mesh broker.

Conclusion

Connecting SAP Process Orchestration with SAP Advanced Event Mesh using JMS and JNDI offers a powerful way to bridge synchronous process-driven integrations with event-driven systems. With Solace’s sol-jms library and proper JNDI configuration, you can seamlessly push data to Advanced Event Mesh queues and unlock real-time integration patterns across your landscape.

While this blog focused on configuring JMS and JNDI for queue-based messaging, which is ideal for point-to-point delivery and tightly scoped integrations, it’s worth noting that a topic-based architecture may be better aligned with future-facing, event-driven designs. Topics enable a publish-subscribe model, allowing multiple systems to consume the same event independently and asynchronously—an essential pattern for building scalable, loosely coupled microservices. As you modernize your integration landscape and move toward more reactive architectures, consider evolving from queue-based patterns to topic-driven messaging to fully embrace the benefits of event-driven architecture.

entry.title: CLASS DEFAULT TIMEZONE
entry.content:
Hello,

The class timezone is by "africa/casablanca" which is UTC+1 but the timezone in the header still displays UTC, how to change it please?

entry.title: SAP Build Process Automation: Test Automation vs Attended Agent Execution
entry.content:
Hello!

I am learning SAP Build Process Automation and have hit an issue I can't seem to find details about online. Hoping someone here can help.

Context:

I have designed a simple automation that does the following:

1. Ask User to Enter in a Value using Input Dialog.

2. Create a New Section in OneNote.

3. Rename Section in OneNote (using Text from Input Dialog).

4. Rename Page in the Section.

5. Add a new Page to the Section.

6. Rename the new Page in the Section, after waiting for 2000ms.

Problem:

When I execute this automation in test mode in the Automation Editor, it works perfectly. When I execute the released version using my Attended Mode Agent, I get the Input Dialog, then the Automation Fails with the following error: "Timeout error: Waiting for screen(s) [Name of Automation Screen] to appear (30 s)."

Why is my test of the automation able to find the screen and execute the automation, but the Attended Agent execution is not able to find the screen and complete the automation.

This is all occurring on my personal desktop. I have not changed the applications open/available between Attended Agent failure and Test Mode success. I can literally run Attended and Test mode back to back repeatedly, and Attended Mode fails, and Test Mode works; every time.

Thank you in advance for any advice.

entry.title: Sending Emails on-behalf of Sales Reps - leveraging any CRM System
entry.content:
Introduction

Email marketing remains one of the most powerful tools in modern marketing. With content personalization, the effectiveness of marketing emails can be significantly improved.SAP Emarsys offers excellent personalization features, available not only within emails but also across multiple channels.

In traditional B2B marketing, emails often serve as a means to generate leads, which are then handed over to the sales organization. The recipients of these emails are typically employees of companies that are either prospects or existing customers. In the latter case, there is usually already a dedicated sales representative—or even an entire account team—responsible for the customer. This creates the opportunity for an enhanced level of personalization by adding sales employee data directly to the email content. Examples include the email header (sender name and address), signature, or closing phrase. This approach also involves sales earlier in the customer journey and reduces the disconnect that is often perceived between marketing and sales.

For some time now the on-behalf feature had been offered as a B2B enhancement when integrating SAP Sales Cloud (Version 1) with SAP Emarsys (See documentation here). In the 2508 release of SAP Emarsys, this feature was generalized to support additional integration scenarios by leveraging the corporate account data object. In the following chapters, I’ll show you how to set this up using the Corporate Account API.

 

Details

Involved Data Entities

Here you see all related data entities needed for the on-behalf feature:

  • Contact
  • Employee (part of the corporate account data product)
  • Corporate Account
    • Contact relation (contacts that belong to a corporate account)
    • Employee relation (account team members, including their role for the specific account)

On-Behalf Personalization Tokens

The following on‑behalf personalization tokens are available under the token group “Account data”:

  • Employee First Name
  • Employee Last Name
  • Employee Email Address
  • Employee Email Address Local (the part before the “@” symbol)
  • Employee Function Name
  • Employee Phone
  • Employee Department Name
  • Employee Address

Determination of the On-Behalf Employee

When personalization tokens are evaluated (i.e., when an email is sent to a specific contact), the following steps take place:

  1. Determine the related corporate account using the contact relation
  2. Determine the on-behalf employee using the employee relation:
    1. Include employees whose employeeRoleCode is either “142” or starts with “BUR011” (standard responsible roles for the responsible employee of an account in SAP Sales Cloud V1 or V2).
    2. If more than one employee matches, only those with isMain = true are considered.

  3. Return data from the identified employee. If a single unique employee is found, their data is inserted; otherwise, an empty string is returned.

Example

If you have contacts with account relations as described—whether from SAP Sales Cloud V1 via AEDI or from integration through the Corporate Account API—you can use the on‑behalf personalization tokens in your campaign content:

 After sending the email the result could look like this:

 

Integration Scenario with Corporate Account API

Preconditions & References

To complete the steps in the next chapters, you’ll need:

  • Basic knowledge on APIs and OAuth / OIDC (Open ID Connect)
  • An API client like Postman or Bruno
  • API credentials with permissions for contact and corporate account operations (contact.*, corporateaccount.*)

Here are some references on APIs:

  • API Authentication
  • Create API Credentials
  • API for Contacts
  • API for Corporate Accounts

Create Data via API

Note: For simplicity reasons I only included one entity in each section (contact, employee, account). 

Create Contact

First I create a contact 'John Doe' with a job position (field id: 17) of 'CEO' (choice id: 2) and a department (field id: 19) of 'Executive' (choice id: 2).

POST .../api/v3/contact

{
  "key_id": "3",
  "contacts": [
    {"1": "John",
     "2": "Doe",
     "3": "john.doe@bp1.acme.com",
     "17": "2",
     "19": "2"
    }
  ]
}

Create Employee

Next, let's create an employee which we will later use as the on-behalf employee (using the PUT variant from now on to be able to make quick changes).

PUT .../api/corporateaccount/v1/employees

[
  {
    "employeeIdField": "employeeId",
    "employeeIdValue": "BP1_Employee_us1",
    "firstName": "Helen",
    "lastName": "Miller",
    "company": "Sonic US",
    "department": "Sales US",
    "function": "Sales Manager",
    "defaultCommunication": {
      "email": "helen.miller@sonic.com",
      "phoneNumber": "+1 452 83045241"
    },
    "defaultAddress": {
      "formattedAddress": "423 Savin St., 02119 Boston, USA"
    }
  }
]

Create Account

Here we create a corporate account with a minimum set of data to make it look good in the account list and factsheet header.

PUT .../api/corporateaccount/v1/accounts/

[
  {
    "formattedOrgName": "ACME Inc.",
    "identifications": {
      "c4cDisplayId": "BP10815"
    },
    "standardIndustrySector": "44",
    "customerClassification": "A",
    "defaultAddress": {
      "country": "US",
      "cityName": "Chicago"
    },
    "defaultCommunication": {
      "website": "www.acme.com"
    }
  }
]

Create Contact relationship

To make the connection from the previously created contact to the new corporate account, let's create a contact relation with the field 'isMain' set to 'true' to make the contact appear in the header of the account factsheet:

PUT .../api/corporateaccount/v1/contactRelations/

[
  {
  "isMain": true,
  "contactIdField": "email",
  "contactIdValue": "john.doe@bp1.acme.com",
  "accountIdField": "identifications/c4cDisplayId",
  "accountIdValue": "BP10815"
  }
]

Create Employee relationship

Finally, let's connect the employee we created to the corporate account as an employee relation with the role code '142'. I also set the 'isMain' flag to 'true' although this would only be relevant if there would be more than one employee in the account relationship with a relevant role code.

PUT .../api/corporateaccount/v1/employeeRelations/

[
  {
  "isMain": true,
  "accountIdField": "identifications/c4cDisplayId",
  "accountIdValue": "BP10815",
  "employeeIdField": "employeeId",
  "employeeIdValue": "BP1_Employee_us1",
  "employeeRoleCode": "142"
  }
]

Test the On-Behalf Feature

Check Account Factsheet

Here is the newly created corporate account in the overview list:

and here is the factsheet (note that the employee is displayed as the the on-behalf employee in the header):

Create and Test an On-Behalf Email Campaign

To test the on-behalf email we need to create an email campaign using the account personalization tokens in both the content and email basics:

Instead of sending the email you can also test the feature by using the contact preview on the top right using the email address of our contact John Doe:

Please also take note of the email basics data on the top.

 

Conclusion

The on-behalf feature in SAP Emarsys provides a powerful way to enhance B2B email personalization by including details of the responsible sales employee in customer communications. By reflecting the direct sales contact in email headers, closings, and signatures, companies can create a more authentic, trustworthy communication experience. This bridges the often-perceived disconnect between marketing and sales by involving sales representatives early in the customer journey. As a result, customers receive messages that feel more personal and aligned with their established relationships, strengthening trust and engagement while making marketing efforts more relevant and effective in the context of ongoing account management.

entry.title: User ID for IAS users
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

We provision users from Entra ID to IAS and then to cloud applications.

In the source system for Entra ID in IAS, we changed the default transformation code (user part):

Instead of:

 

 {
        "sourcePath": "$.userPrincipalName",
        "targetPath": "$.userName",
        "correlationAttribute": true
      },

we use:

{
  "sourcePath": "$.employeeId",
  "targetPath": "$.userName",
  "correlationAttribute": true
}

This way, the employee ID from Entra is provisioned to the Login Name field in IAS. When provisioning to the cloud application, a user is created with the employee ID as the user ID.

employeeId

Entra ID (employeeId) → Login Name (IAS) → User ID (SAC)

Problem:
Users created directly in IAS don’t have an employee ID, so the Login Name field in IAS is empty.

Question:
What can be used as the user ID in the cloud apps for users created directly in IAS?

 

Thank you very much for any tips

Best Regards

entry.title: Make To Stock MRP set up for each sales order requirement and planned order creation
entry.content:
The business wants us to create planned orders separately for each sales order requirement, even though this is a make-to-stock scenario. The planned order should be created per sales order, and the stock should be received as unrestricted stock in SAP ECC.

 

Currently, the material master is set up as follows:

  • MRP type: PD

  • Lot size: EX (no min/max quantity)

  • Ind/Collective indicator: 01

  • Availability check: 02

  • Strategy group: 40

 

Example: Two sales orders are created for material X, each with a quantity of 1 and the same requirement date. Instead of generating two separate planned orders (1 per sales order), the system is combining them into a single planned order with quantity 2.

 

Question: How can we configure the system so that it generates one planned order for each sales order separately, even though the sales order requirement date is the same in an MTS setup?

entry.title: Automatic Purchase Requisition to Purchase order- W/O Material numbers
entry.content:
We have a requirement to automatically convert Purchase Requisitions to Purchase Orders without material numbers (Service PO's and other material purchases w/o material numbers). For these PO's,  we use free texts in the PO line items along with the material group.  A single material group can be used for multiple free text line items and it makes a little challenging to create the Purchasing Info Records to maintain the prices for automation purposes. Please advise if anyone who have came across this situation or if there is a way to tackle it. Thanks. 

@BijayKumarBarik

entry.title: Re: फोनपे से गलत न बर पर कैसे चला जाए तो क्या करें?

Regards

Christian

entry.title: How to in B2B retrieve all assigned policies (manually and automatically) for user
entry.content:
Hi,

In the B2B Module we've setup policies which are automatically assigned to user (based on filters). Within the login process this works fine.

But when I call account.getAccountInfo and read all the policies within the groups/organizations, I only get those which are manually assigned to the user.

How do I get all assigned (manually and automatically) roles/policies from one user? If there is not one api to get all the roles, how do I get the automatically assigned roles additionally? 

Thank you

 


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: How to in B2B retrieve all assigned policies (manuall...
entry.content:
In order to retrieve the relationship information between an account and an organization, including all policies assigned to the user (either manually or through automated assignments) and for each policy which applications the user has access to please use API call with accounts.b2b.getAccountOrganizationInfo REST

Make sure to add in request all relevant parameters as per documentation.

entry.title: Re: SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud : Setup Client ID/Secret, Us...
entry.content:
Hello @yashoratna 

The behaviour you observe when creating a communication user in S4 HANA Public Cloud, where the Username field demands a specific format, such as an email address, is expected.

For detailed official guidance on managing communication users and authentication in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, including user creation, password management, and integration best practices, check out these important SAP documents.

SAP Help: Manage Communication Users
This explains how to create and maintain communication users, including naming conventions and password management in S/4HANA Cloud.

SAP Help: Configure Authentication for Communication Users
Explains the different authentication options available, such as OAuth and user credentials, to help you easily connect with external systems.

SAP Best Practice Guide: Integration via Communication Users and OAuth
This section provides helpful suggestions for integrating secure authentication and communication when setting up users in SAP S/4HANA Cloud public edition. It aims to guide you smoothly through best practices, making your setup process easier and more secure.

These resources offer the official guidelines on naming conventions and the best practices for using communication users for third-party integration while ensuring system security and compliance.

If direct User ID input is restricted, adhere to the SAP naming standards and utilise these communication users for authentication in your external integration scenarios.

Let me know if it works

With regards

Chuma

SAP Business Accelerator Hub

To implement this functionality, you will need expertise in local extension development. Once developed, you can leverage this functionality using the API mentioned below.

Database Access | SAP Help Portal

entry.title: Re: Can I install multiple versions of SAP Crystal Report...
entry.content:
It is not possible if both are 32-bit or both are 64-bit.

But it is possible if one is 32-bit and the other is 64-bit. I have many customers that deploy my software in such a way to avoid conflict with legacy applications that include older service packs of the Crystal runtime.

entry.title: Personalizing Success with SAP CX AI Toolkit: Unlocking Value with Custom Tool Builder
entry.content:
Introduction

Customer expectations are higher than ever. They want fast answers, personalized interactions, and consistent experiences across every touchpoint. Businesses know this, but delivering on it—at scale—hasn’t been easy. That’s where the SAP CX AI Toolkit comes in.

The SAP CX AI Toolkit offers ready-to-use AI features, and the Custom Tool Builder, the focus of this blog - adds the flexibility to tailor solutions to your business and industry needs. No generic responses, no one-size-fits-all. Just tools that give your teams exactly what they need—whether it’s a sales rep preparing for a meeting, a service agent handling a customer request, or a product manager optimizing digital storefronts.

…and the Custom Tool Builder delivers business impact that is both commendable and strategically important— illustrated in the example use case flow below:

In this blog, we’ll explore how the Custom Tool Builder creates real value in SAP Sales Cloud V1, SAP Service Cloud V2, and SAP Commerce Cloud. To make it practical, we’ll walk through role-specific journeys and show how syntax, prompts, and outcomes connect directly to business results.

How It Works – Syntax & Prompt Basics

Administrators can use the AI Tools Builder to design custom prompts grounded in SAP Cloud for Customer or SAP Sales & Service Cloud Version 2 data.
The goal: craft prompts that guide the AI to produce accurate, relevant, and business-aligned outputs.

Guiding Principles of Prompt Engineering

  1. Define the Context - Clarify the AI’s role (e.g., “as a sales assistant, Service Agent, Commerce Manager..”) and the intended audience.
  2. Set the Desired Outcome - State the goal: What action, insight, or response do you expect?
  3. Provide Clear Guidance  - Be specific about context, outcome, tone, style, and format. Use examples to illustrate the expected output, Focus on what the AI should do (not what it shouldn’t), and add reference text or fields for grounding responses.
  4. Start Simple, Then Iterate - Begin with zero-shot prompting (no examples) to test the possible results, then move to one-shot (single example) or few-shot (multiple examples) for better accuracy. Also, break down complex tasks into smaller ones.

Example:

Example – Syntax, Data Entities and Sources:

  • Standard Fields: Personalize responses with fields like {{ContactPerson.givenName}}.
  • Custom Fields: Extend prompts with fields unique to your business.
  • Wild Cards (*): Pull all available fields dynamically, including new ones when data changes.
  • Multiple Related Records (CRM): Use {{EntityName.List.EntityName}} to reference related data (e.g., all opportunities linked to an account).
  • Multiple Related Records (Commerce): Use similar references to ground prompts in Commerce Cloud data.

Key Takeaway: By defining context, guiding outputs clearly, and grounding prompts in SAP CX data (standard, custom, wildcards, or related records), administrators can unlock more personalized, accurate, and business-relevant AI responses.

More information can be found here: Create a Custom AI Tool And Prompt Engineering Tips for AI Tools Builder.

 

📌✨🛠️...Now, let’s make it practical with some few examples.

 

Sales Cloud V1 – The Account 360 Every Rep & Managers Wants

 

  • The challenge: Preparing for meetings is time-consuming. Data is scattered across accounts, opportunities, notes, and service cases.
  • Who benefits: Sales Representatives / Sales Managers and other Sales Roles
  • The solution: A custom Account 360 tool that generates a clean, role-relevant summary.

Use case Description

This AI tool gives sales reps a 360-degree view of the customer account by pulling together account details, key opportunities, recent visits, service tickets, and notes. Instead of spending hours preparing, reps receive a ready-to-use summary in seconds, empowering them to walk into meetings fully prepared.

Prompt Example:

# CONTEXT # 

As a Sales Representative working for the Machinery Industry focused on steel production, I need a detailed summary of the account.

# OBJECTIVE #

This tool is designed to assist sales representatives in managing customer relationships efficiently, being better prepared for negotiations, and providing a true 360° customer view. The output should be based entirely on grounded SAP Sales Cloud V1 data.

# FURTHER INSTRUCTION FOR STYLE #

Write in a professional, neutral, and concise way. Use clear section headings (e.g., "Account Overview," "Opportunities," "Notes") and bullet points for readability. Add relevant emojis where they make the response more user-friendly.

# TASK #

Executive Summary:

Evaluate engagement based on relationships attached to the following entities: Account Detail, Activities, Leads, Opportunities, and Tickets:

     Activities: Most relevant ones only
     Leads: Most relevant ones only
     Opportunities: Highlight top 3 high-value ones
     Account Detail & Notes: Summarize recent interactions
     Service Cases: Mention open tickets with key details

Account details: {{CorporateAccount.*}}
Activities: {{CorporateAccount.List.Appointment}} {{CorporateAccount.List.PhoneCall}} {{CorporateAccount.List.Tasks}}
Leads: {{CorporateAccount.List.Lead}}
Opportunities: {{CorporateAccount.List.Opportunity}}
Service Tickets: {{CorporateAccount.List.ServiceRequest}}

-> Test it via playground and activate it.

Example of the configuration and outcome:

The Sales user can make it as favorite and use the new AI tool from the web application:

 

or through a web browser extension with in-context capability for SAP Sales Cloud V1. This means that when a user accesses a specific account, the input (specific account) automatically connects to that CX AI toolkit —eliminating the need for the sales employee to manually filter or search for it. Example below:

and More about this feature here - User Interfaces - WebApp

 

Why this custom AI Tool matters: Instead of wasting time digging through multiple tabs, reps walk into ready and focused meetings. They know the customer’s latest concerns, hottest opportunities, and any risks. That confidence translates into higher win rates and stronger relationships.

 

Service Cloud V2 – Handling Tickets with Empathy - Template for delay in resolving cases

  • The challenge: Customers expect empathy and clarity, even when things go wrong. But agents are often pressed for time and may default to generic replies & translation is needed to cope with different languages.
  • Who benefits: Service Agents
  • The solution: A tool that automatically crafts empathetic, customer-specific updates when tickets are delayed.

AI Use Case Description:

This AI tool helps service agents communicate ticket delays empathetically and consistently. By grounding prompts in SAP Service Cloud case data, it automatically generates customer-facing emails that explain revised due dates and reasons for delays, all while maintaining a professional, caring tone & content translated.

Prompt Example:

# OBJECTIVE #

Help agents send empathetic, transparent updates that maintain trust—even in tricky situations. Also translate to English, Spanish, French, and Brazilian Portuguese, as these are the usual contact languages.

# FURTHER INSTRUCTION FOR STYLE #

Be professional yet warm. Keep it short and clear. Use emojis sparingly (‌‌ for delays, ‌‌ for commitments) to soften the message without losing professionalism.

# TASK #

Write an email that:

- Explains the revised due date.

- States the reason for the delay.

- Acknowledges the inconvenience while reaffirming commitment to resolution.

Case ID: {{Case.displayId}}
Case Contact: {{Case.contact.name}}
Case Type Description:  {{Case.caseTypeDescription}}
Original Due Date: {{Case.timePoints.completionDueOn}}

 

Test it via playground and activate it.

Example of the configuration and outcome:

 

The Service Agent user can make it as favorite and use the new AI tool from the web application  & & copy and paste the template/outcome easily:

or through CX AI toolkit embedded capability for SAP Service Cloud V2. This means that when a user accesses a specific case, the input (specific case) in the CX AI toolkit is embedded/connected to that Case — eliminating the need for the sales employee to manually filter or search for it. Example below:

 

and More about this feature here - User Interfaces - Embedded Panel: SAP Sales and Service Cloud Version 2

 Why this custom AI Tool matters:  Instead of frustrated customers, you get reassured ones. Clear communication reduces escalations and improves satisfaction scores. And every agent—whether new or experienced—maintains the same high standard.

 

Commerce Cloud – SEO That Scales

 

  • The challenge: Optimizing thousands of products for SEO is impossible to do manually.
  • Who benefits: E-Commerce Product Managers
  • The solution: A tool that generates optimized titles and descriptions, automatically grounded in product data.

 AI Use Case Description:
This AI tool enables product managers to scale SEO optimization effortlessly across the entire product catalog. By grounding in SAP Commerce Cloud product data, it generates meta titles and descriptions aligned with search engine best practices, increasing visibility, traffic, and conversions.

 Prompt Example:

The goal of this use case is to streamline the generation of SEO-optimized meta titles and descriptions for eCommerce products, enhancing visibility and click-through rates (CTRs) on search engine results pages (SERPs). This current tool builder utilizes the {{Product.*}} catalog and generates the meta title for {{Product.name}} and {{Product.defaultDescription}} ensuring that each meta title and description is unique, relevant, and adheres to SEO best practices. Also, take these instructions in consideration:

Meta Title Generation:

Length: Keep titles under 60 characters to avoid truncation in SERPs.

Structure: Place primary keywords at the beginning of the title.

Uniqueness: Ensure each title is distinct by incorporating product-specific details (e.g., size, color).

Call to Action: If space allows, include compelling phrases like “Free Shipping” or “Shop Now” to enhance clickability.

Example Output:

“Red Running Shoes – Lightweight & Breathable | Free Shipping”

Meta Description Generation

Length: Aim for 155–160 characters to ensure full visibility.

Content: Summarize key product features, benefits, and USPs while incorporating primary keywords.

Call to Action: Include actionable phrases such as “Discover More” or “Buy Today” to encourage clicks.

Uniqueness: Avoid duplication by tailoring descriptions to specific products.

Example Output:

“Shop our Red Running Shoes designed for comfort and speed. Lightweight, breathable fabric ensures a perfect fit. Buy today with free shipping!”

Example Outputs: - Title: “Elegant Silk Evening Dress,  Backless | Shop Now”
- Description: “Turn heads in our silk evening dress with a stunning backless design. Perfect for formal events. Order now for free shipping! ”

 

Test it via playground and activate it.

Example of the configuration and outcome:

The E-Commerce Product Managers user can make it as favorite and use the new AI tool from the web application & copy and paste the outcome easily:

 

Why this AI tool matters: Instead of being buried on page three of Google, your products get found. More visibility means more traffic, which means more sales. And all without manually writing thousands of descriptions.

 

Wrapping Up

The Custom Tool Builder isn’t just another feature—it’s a way to unlock AI’s real potential in your business. By grounding prompts in SAP CX data, you ensure every output is:

  • Relevant: Specific to your business and your customers.
  • Consistent: On-brand and reliable across teams.
  • Efficient: Saving hours of manual work.
  • Impactful: Driving higher revenue, better customer satisfaction, and stronger loyalty.

In short, the Custom Tool Builder takes AI from being a generic assistant to becoming a trusted business partner for SAP Sales, Service, and Commerce Cloud.

We hope you have enjoyed the reading,
Thank you,

Luciano Monteiro,

CX Solution Value Advisory team.

entry.title: Re: Calculated Measure Temporary creation - SAC for plann...
entry.content:
@Deb_D 

You did not mention what will be the logic of the Measures you intend to create. From what you wrote it seems you want some restricted or filtered measures. You could use Restricted measures with Input controls to select the restriction parameters.

Scripting cannot create measures as such it can just help with UI task, setting filters on table etc. May be you can use them in combination but it will be helpful if you define the measure logic in detail or with an example.

Hope this helps !

Nikhil

entry.title: Re: How are SAP teams ensuring compliance with MCA Rule 1...
entry.content:
Hello @Udayaaa ,

To ensure full compliance with MCA Rule 11(g) in your SAP environment, it is crucial to establish a strong, tamper-resistant audit trail system that maintains all accounting transaction logs for a minimum of eight years, as required by the Ministry of Corporate Affairs.

Here are some important steps to help you reach this goal:

  • Enabling immutable audit logs at both application and database levels to ensure logs cannot be disabled, altered, or deleted by any user, including administrators.
  • Establish continuous daily monitoring and alerting to detect any tampering attempts or suspicious activities in real-time.
  • Aligning with KBA 3042258, which outlines statutory requirements for audit trail maintenance in SAP systems.
  • Utilising advanced security solutions such as ThreatSenseAI for automatic detection, restoration, and reporting of audit trails anomalies.
  • Implementing strict access controls and segregation of duties to prevent unauthorised manipulation of audit logs.
  • Keeping your system in an audit-ready state all year round to facilitate smooth statutory audits with no compliance gaps.

For detailed guidance, we recommend reviewing KBA 3042258 and the comprehensive framework provided by ToggleNow. at SAP Compliance for MCA Rule 11(g).

Implementing these measures will assist your SAP landscape in meeting and surpassing MCA Rule 11(g) requirements, delivering dependable, tamper-proof audit trails that uphold the integrity of your financial data throughout the mandated retention period.

Let me know if you need further support

With kind regards

Chuma
